awd_titl_txt: EAGER: An Exploratory Study of R&D Investment on Innovation using Business R&D and Innovation Survey (BRDIS) Data
awd_abstract_narration:
Innovation has been examined from multiple perspectives nevertheless; the impact of process and product innovation on firm performance is mixed. To better estimate the relationship between R&D investment and firm performance, this project will consider new data that allows for a clear distinction between different forms of R&D investment, product vs. process innovation and firm performance. 

The National Center for Science and Engineering Statistics (NCSES) Business Research and Development Survey (BRDIS) data provide rich data firm level to examine the effect of R&D investment on firm product innovation and process innovation, through the Census Bureau Census Data Center. This exploratory work will begin to examine the data series that begins in 2011.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Social, Behavioral and Economic Sciences

por.por_cntn:
To remain competitive and become responsive to customer demand, organizations should strengthen their innovation capabilities. In that regard, understanding the impact of investment in research and development (R&D) on innovation outcomes has important insights for organizations to address technological innovation.

In this research, we examined the relationship between R&D investment, product innovation, and process innovation using longitudinal data from the Business R&D Survey (BRDIS). We found that while there is a relationship between R&D investment and innovation outcomes, such a relationship is different for organizations with different sizes (measured by the number of employees). One important aspect of the study is to address the distinction between large and small and medium-sized organizations (typically organizations with less than 500 employees). We found that organizations with different sizes exhibit different patterns for the relationship between R&D investment and innovation, which has important science and innovation policy implications. 

We also found that collaborative R&D is an important predictor of innovation outcomes. This is important as organizations explore development of new products and processes through partnerships, joint ventures, and strategic alliances. While larger organizations typically have more resources to allocate for technological innovation initiatives, development of collaborative R&D projects should be viewed an effective innovation strategy to strengthen the innovation outcomes for organizations.
